sep.mvc

Class AbstractView

  • java.lang.Object
    • sep.mvc.AbstractView

  • public abstract class AbstractView
extends java.lang.Object
    A View provides the front-end user interface, which includes appropriate presentation of the relevant model data to the user. The lifetime of an MVC application is often tied to its front-end UI.

    The View accepts user input, and conveys the corresponding commands to the registered Controller for processing. The View interacts closely with the Controller, but should not be coupled to any particular Controller (i.e., a View should be interoperable with different Controllers).

    A View may itself determine when it should be updated, and retrieve the required information directly from the Model, or operations performed on the Model (as directed by the Controller) may actively push updates to the View, or some combination thereof. The design can depend on whether the UI supports synchronous or asynchronous user interactions.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Modifier Constructor and Description
      protected AbstractView()
      This View is created without a registered Controller.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Concrete Methods

      Close this View.

      Get the Controller registered to this View, if any.
      protected AbstractModel getModel()
      Get the model bound to the registered Controller, if a Controller has been registered.
      void init()
      Initialise this View.
      abstract void run()
      Start the main UI loop.
      protected void setController(AbstractController control)
      Registers the Controller if one has not been registered so far; otherwise the supplied Controller is shut down.
      abstract void update()
      Update the presentation of the front-end UI.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractView

        protected AbstractView()
        This View is created without a registered Controller. A Controller is registered by passing this View when the Controller is created.
        See Also:
        setController(sep.mvc.AbstractController)

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init()
        Initialise this View. To be called once, and only once, before run().

        May be called by the top-level application bootstrapper (e.g., the main method).

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If no Controller has been registered.

      • close

        public abstract void close()
        Close this View. This operation is idempotent.

      • run

        public abstract void run()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Start the main UI loop. That is, maintain an up-to-date presentation of the front-end user interface (e.g., via update()), and interpret user input as commands for the Controller to process.

        May be called by the top-level application bootstrapper (e.g., the main method) after init has been called.

        Precondition: init() has been called.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If a user input error occurs

      • update

        public abstract void update()
        Update the presentation of the front-end UI. May be called by run(), or from the model/Controller, as appropriate for the application and UI design.

      • getController

        protected AbstractController getController()
        Get the Controller registered to this View, if any.
        Returns:
        The registered Controller, if any
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If no Controller has been registered

      • getModel

        protected AbstractModel getModel()
        Get the model bound to the registered Controller, if a Controller has been registered.
        Returns:
        The bound model, if a Controller has been registered
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If no Controller has been registered

      • setController

        protected void setController(AbstractController control)
        Registers the Controller if one has not been registered so far; otherwise the supplied Controller is shut down. Implicitly called by the AbstractController.AbstractController(AbstractModel, AbstractView) constructor. Normally, you should not need to override this method.
        Parameters:
        control - The Controller to register
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If registering a null Controller
